page.para: Ha/ri/ta has a loose tooth. “Look grand/ma, my tooth is loose!” she says.
“That’s o/kay, child,” says grand/ma. “When it falls out, a new tooth will grow.”
“I can pull the tooth out,” says grand/ma. “O/kay, grand/ma,” says Ha/ri/ta.
So grand/ma ties a thread a/round the tooth, and pulls. The tooth pops out.
“Eeek, my tooth!” says Ha/ri/ta. “What will I do with it, grand/ma?”
“Throw it on the roof for the crow,” said grand/ma. “And make a wish.”
Ha/ri/ta finds a piece of char/coal, and sticks the tooth in/to it.
One, two, three! Ha/ri/ta throws the char/coal on/to the roof, and makes a wish.
“What did you wish for?” asks A/dit/ya. “It’s a se/cret,” says Ha/ri/ta.
“Grand/ma, I will brush my new tooth eve/ry day,” says Ha/ri/ta. Grand/ma smiles.
